According to the [[International Committee of the Red Cross|Red Cross]], ambulances were not given permission to enter the neighborhood to retrieve the injured from the building until a day later.<ref name=IHTJan4>{{cite news|title=In heart of conflict, Gaza civilians hit hard|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/04/mideast/scene.php|work=International Herald Tribune|date=4 Jan 2009}}</ref><ref name=TDTJan9>{{cite news|author=Tim Butcher|title=Gaza bombing witnesses describe horror of Israeli strike|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/4209550/Gaza-bombing-witnesses-describe-horror-of-Israeli-strike.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=9 January 2009|accessdate=24 Jan 2009 | location=London}}</ref> The United Nations confirmed these reports on 9 January<ref name=NYT9Jan/> Three children later died after they were transported to hospital.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7819937.stm|title=Call for Zeitoun investigation|publisher=BBC News | date=9 January 2009 | accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> Reports of the incident were given to the media by Norwegian doctors stationed in the Shifa Hospital, Gaza, as early as Tuesday, 5 January.<ref>[http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/uriks/midtosten/article2850359.ece Familien hennes ble utslettet] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524050433/http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/uriks/midtosten/article2850359.ece |date=24 May 2011 }}, by Olav Røli, [[Aftenposten]], 5. January 2009</ref>
[[B'Tselem]], an Israeli human rights group, alleged that Israeli forces had not done their duty to prevent civilian casualties by assisting the wounded. 48 hours after the attack, [[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]] ambulances searching 100 yards from where Israeli soldiers were stationed found four children, too weak to move, that had taken refuge near corpses believed to be those of their family.<ref name=TDT9JanUNwc>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/4209242/Israeli-strike-on-civilian-house-may-be-war-crime-says-UN-gaza.html|title=Israeli strike on civilian house may be 'war crime' says UN|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=9 January 2009|accessdate=24 Jan 2009| location=London | first=Tim | last=Butcher}}</ref><ref name=TDT9JanUNwc/> "The ICRC believes that in this instance the Israeli military failed to meet its obligation under international humanitarian law to care for and evacuate the wounded," said a statement from the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent]], and called the delay considers the delay in granting access "unacceptable".<ref name=TDT9JanUNwc/>
Other buildings were reported as being shelled during the incident,<ref name=NYT9Jan/><ref name=IHT5Jan>{{cite news|title=Israel pushes deeper into Gaza, rebuffing truce efforts|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/05/africa/06mideast.php|date=5 January 2009}}</ref> and IDF infantry reportedly fired on an occupied house<ref name=IHTJan4/> The survivors of the incident were treated at Shifa hospital, Gaza.<ref name=IHT5Jan/>
The IDF stated that it had no knowledge of the incident, and that "IDF forces had not yet reached the areas in question" by 4 January.<ref name=Ynet>{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3653417,00.html|title=UN: IDF shelled evacuated civilians}}</ref> An Israeli army spokesman said there was no record of a "specific attack on a specific target", nor had the army massed civilians in specific locations. "This does not rule out exchanges of fire but it does rule out targeting of a specific building," he said.<ref name=TDTJan9/> Israel said there is not a humanitarian crisis in Gaza and that it is working with international agencies and doing what it can to reduce civilian casualties.<ref name=TDT9JanUNwc/>
The UN's [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|OCHA]] said that if it was true it was "one of the gravest incidents" in the conflict,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article5480440.ece|title=War in Gaza: Israel accused of shelling house full of children|date=9 January 2009|publisher=[[The Times]] Online|author1=Philippe Naughton |author2=Martin Fletcher | location=London}}</ref> and called for an investigation into the incident, but did not make any "accusations of deliberate action" at the time. United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, [[Navanethem Pillay]], said the Zeitoun Samouni incident "appears to have all the elements of war crimes."<ref name=NYT9Jan/><ref name=TDT9JanUNwc/> Pillay called for "credible, independent and transparent" investigations into possible violations of humanitarian law.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/09/gaza-palestinians-israel-evacuees-zeitoun UN levels war crimes warning at Israel], ''The Guardian'', 9 January 2009.</ref>
====5 January 2009==== As Israeli tanks and troops seized control of large parts of the Gaza Strip, tens of thousands of Gazans fled their homes amidst artillery and gunfire, and flooded into the heart of [[Gaza City]].<ref>{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Rory|title=Thousands flee guns and shells as Israel tightens grip on Gaza|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/05/israel-palestine-gaza-attacks|date=5 January 2009 | work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> Gun battles reportedly broke out between Israel and Hamas on the streets of Gaza, as Israeli forces surrounded the city.<ref name=reutersjan5/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/05/israel-palestine-gaza-attacks1 Israeli troops and Hamas fighters clash in Gaza City] ''[[Guardian.co.uk]]''. 5 January 2009.</ref> BBC reporters stated that the battles were preventing essential medical supplies from reaching hospitals and casualties.<ref name=bbcjan5/>
An airstrike hit an ambulance, killing three paramedics.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD95GNHK80 The Associated Press: Israeli troops and tanks slice deep into Gaza<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Israeli tank shelling killed at least 24 civilians in the Gaza Strip,<ref>{{cite news|title=Israeli tank shelling kills at least 24,Palestinians|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90852/6567488.html|date=5 January 2009}}</ref> 13 of them children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Israeli shelling kills 24 civilians, including two families|url=http://www.sindhtoday.net/south-asia/48130.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121004756/http://www.sindhtoday.net/south-asia/48130.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 January 2009|date=5 January 2009|publisher=Sindh Today}}</ref> A family of seven were killed by an Israeli airstrike in [[al-Shati Camp]] east of Gaza City.<ref name=bbcjan5/> In Gaza's Zaytun neighborhood, seven members of another family were killed and in separate incident, a pregnant Palestinian woman and her four children were killed.<ref name=autogenerated2>Harel, Amos. [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053120.html Three IDF soldiers killed, one critically wounded in Gaza blast] ''[[Haaretz]]''. 5 January 2009.</ref>
Media reported that Israel was using the controversial substance [[White phosphorus (weapon)|white phosphorus]] over civilian targets during the course of its military operation.<ref name="DailyMail_WP">[http://aftermathnews.wordpress.com/2009/01/05/gaza-death-toll-soars-past-500-as-israel-is-accused-of-using-banned-phosphorus-shells/ ''Gaza death toll soars past 500 as Israel is accused of using banned phosphorus shells'']. Matthew Kalman, Daily Mail, 5 January 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1105127/At-14-children-killed-Gaza-terror-Israel-defies-demands-ceasefire.html ''At least 14 children killed in Gaza terror as Israel defies demands for a ceasefire'']. Matthew Kalman and David Williams, Daily Mail, 5 January 2009</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gordon Brown calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza |url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article5447544.ece |date=5 January 2009|publisher=[[Times Online]] | location=London | first1=James | last1=Bone | first2=Francis | last2=Elliott | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> Some media reported that Israel used the substance as a smokescreen.<ref>{{cite news | title=Israel ready to slice through heart of Gaza|author1=John Lyons |date=6 January 2009 | publisher=The Australian| url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24878292-601,00.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Israel uses phosphorus shells as smokescreen for troops| author=Robert Mendick |date=5 January 2009 | publisher=Evening Standard| url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23611375-details/Israel+uses+phosphorus+shells+as+smokescreen+for+troops/article.do}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Israel rains fire on Gaza with phosphorus shells|author1=Sheera Frenkel |author2=Michael Evans |lastauthoramp=yes |date=5 January 2009 | publisher=[[Times Online]]| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article5447590.ece | location=London}}</ref> Israel used white phosphorus in Lebanon in 2006, and the UK and the US have used it elsewhere. Israel denied using the substance.<ref name="DailyMail_WP" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sify.com/news/fullstory.php?id=14830411|title=Page Not Found|work=sify.com}}</ref> According to [[Ha'aretz]] and the UN humanitarian chief, Israel had also used [[cluster bomb]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/01/07/stories/2009010754191700.htm|title=40 die in Israeli strike at school|publisher=The Hindu | location=Chennai, India|date=7 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Amos Harel|title=Massive artillery, aerial bombardment precedes invasion by IDF ground forces|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1052331.html|date=5 January 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117005431/http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1052331.html|archivedate=17 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Hamas said it would send a delegation to Egypt for talks, as France spearheaded diplomatic efforts to obtain a 48-hour truce.<ref name=reutersjan5/> Israel continued to refuse to let journalists enter the Gaza Strip, despite a ruling from the [[Israeli Supreme Court]] to admit a limited number of reporters.<ref name=bbcjan5>{{cite news|title=Envoys race to halt Gaza carnage|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7810945.stm|date=5 January 2009|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
Over 40 [[Qassam rocket|Qassam]] and [[Grad rockets]] were fired from Gaza at southern Israel striking [[Ashkelon]], [[Ashdod]], [[Sderot]], [[Kiryat Malakhi]], near [[Ofakim]], [[Netivot]] and [[Beersheba]]. Hamas also fired rockets at the area between Ashdod and [[Gedera]].
Hamas said they have killed 9 Israeli fighters.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Hamas says 9 Israeli soldiers killed |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20090104-181325/Hamas-says-9-Israeli-soldiers-killed |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522115540/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/world/view/20090104-181325/Hamas-says-9-Israeli-soldiers-killed |archivedate=22 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Hamas also said they have captured two Israeli soldiers. Israel dismissed the claims, accusing Hamas of engaging in "psychological warfare".<ref name="Haaretz2">{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1052544.html|title=Report: Hamas holding 2 Israeli soldiers; IDF: No knowledge of report}}</ref> By evening, the Israeli Defense Forces said that during the course of the day they had killed between 80-100 Hamas fighters in ground fighting, and that a further 100 "wanted gunmen" had been taken prisoner. Palestinian cells fired nearly 40 rockets and mortar shells at Israel, injuring four Israelis.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651124,00.html Hamas adamant to strike back at IDF] [''Ynetnews'']</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debka.com/|title=DEBKAfile, Political Analysis, Espionage, Terrorism, Security|publisher=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
An IDF spokesperson stated that three Israeli soldiers were killed in a [[friendly fire]] incident<ref name="ynetnews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651164,00.html|title=Gaza: 3 soldiers killed in friendly fire incident|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> after erroneously identifying Israeli soldiers as "terrorists."<ref name="ynewnews_6th_soldier_confirmation">{{cite news|title=Tank and infantry operations in Gaza investigated|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651434,00.html|date=6 January 2009}}</ref> About 20 soldiers were injured in the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651165,00.html|title=Gaza: 3 soldiers killed, 24 injured in friendly fire incident|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> Another IDF officer was reported killed in a separate friendly fire incident.<ref name="englishil">[http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/the_Front/09/01/0602.htm Operation Cast Lead Continues: Paratrooper Brigade Officer Killed<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124001227/http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/the_Front/09/01/0602.htm |date=24 January 2009 }}</ref>
UN officials published a report which stated that an Israeli airstrike on the grounds of a UN school, which was serving as a makeshift refugee camp for hundreds of displaced Palestinians, killed three Palestinian men.<ref name=APIHT0601>{{cite news|title=3 men killed in Israeli airstrike at UN school|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2009/01/06/news/ML-Gaza-UN-School.php|agency=Associated Press|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=6 January 2008|date=6 January 2009}}</ref> An official from the Danish charitable organization DanChurchAid reported that three mobile clinics set up to help hospitals in Gaza cope with the wounded were bombarded in Israeli airstrikes, despite being clearly marked as humanitarian vehicles.<ref name=AFP0601>{{cite web|title=Three Danish Mobile Clinics Destroyed In Gaza - Charity|date=6 January 2009|url=http://www.easybourse.com/bourse-actualite/marches/three-danish-mobile-clinics-destroyed-in-gaza-charity-591345|accessdate=6 January 2009|publisher=Easybourse|author=Agence France Presse}}</ref>
A total of 30 Palestinian civilians were known to have been killed on 5 January, and the total Palestinian death toll at the end of the day was 540,<ref>{{cite news|author=Nidal al-Mughrabi|title=Israel deaf to truce calls as Gaza battles rage on|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/usTopNews/idUKLS69391620090105|date=5 January 2009|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> until details of the Samouni family incident (below) emerged several days later.
====6 January 2009==== According to Palestinian sources, 20 people were killed in a number of IDF attacks. Medical workers reported that an attack on [[Deir al-Balah]] and the [[Bureij]] refugee camp killed ten Palestinians, including a father and his three children. An IDF soldier was killed and four wounded in an ambush in northern Gaza City.<ref name=Ynetupdate>{{cite web|title=Cleared for publication: IDF soldier killed in northern Gaza|date=6 January 2009|publisher=[[YNET]]|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651651,00.html|accessdate=1 June 2009}}</ref> The IDF soldiers returned fire, killing all of the Hamas fighters. The IDF soldier killed was identified as Alexander Mashevitzky. According to [[YNET]], the head of Hamas' artillery forces and a senior member of Hamas' military wing, Ayman Siam, were both hit and believed to have been killed in an aerial attack in the [[Jabaliya]] neighborhood in the northern Gaza Strip.<ref name=ynet_siam>{{cite web|title=Hamas rocket unit head believed killed in IDF strike |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651369,00.html |date=6 January 2009|accessdate=1 June 2009|publisher=[[YNET]]|author=[[Hanan Greenberg]] }}</ref><ref name=ynet_siam/>
At least 30 rockets were fired into Israel from Gaza.<ref name=Ynet0601/> [[Gedera]], {{convert|30|km|mi}} south of Tel Aviv, was hit for the first time.<ref name=Haaretz0601>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053139.html|title=Gaza rocket hits Gedera, 30km from Tel Aviv; baby lightly hurt|author=Haaretz services|publisher=[[Haaretz]]|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118014812/http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053139.html|archivedate=18 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A Grad rocket landed near a house, lightly injuring a 3-month old girl.<ref name=Ynet0601>{{Cite news|title=Infant lightly hurt in rocket attack on Gedera|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651267,00.html}}</ref>
"There's nowhere safe in Gaza", said [[John Ging]], the UN's senior official in Gaza. "Everyone is terrorized and traumatized." He spoke of 1 million Palestinians without electricity and 700,000 without water, challenging world leaders to undergo similar privations until they had stopped the fighting: "You are not to sleep, eat or drink until you stop the killing of innocent people in the Gaza Strip".<ref name=Burai>{{cite news|title=Israel strikes deeper into Gaza|author1=Ahmed Burai |author2=Jeffrey Fleishman |lastauthoramp=yes |date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-gaza7-2009jan07,0,6192771.story | work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
Israel continued to refuse foreign journalists' access to the Gaza Strip. The continuing ban on foreign media access drew criticism from journalists that Israel was trying to "manage" the story. Israel said that opening border crossings for journalists would endanger staff at the terminals. While the [[Associated Press]] and some other news organizations have Palestinian reporters, photographers and cameramen based in Gaza, many media outlets have no reliable source of independent information.<ref name=Max_050109>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090121150832/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=6578931 ''Israel's Propangada War: Reporters Banned From Gaza'']. ARTHUR MAX, Associated Press, 5 January 2009. On web.archive.org</ref>
Medics report that an Israeli airstrike on a 4-story building in Gaza City the night before had killed 12 members of the same extended family; the bodies of 7 children aged one to twelve years old, 3 women and 2 men from the Daya family were pulled from the rubble on Tuesday.<ref name=HeraldSun0701>{{cite news|title=At least 20 killed in Israeli strike on United Nations school|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24882704-663,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121230132203/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24882704-663,00.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 December 2012|date=7 January 2009|accessdate=1 June 2009|publisher=Herald Sun|author=[[Agence France Presse]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7814054.stm | work=BBC News | title=Strike at Gaza school 'kills 40' | date=7 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
Senior Israeli defense officials said that Hamas had set up independent hospitals, and had stolen Israeli aid supplies.<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231167266926&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull], ''Jerusalem Post'', 6 January 2009</ref>
A senior IDF officer said that "tunnels, weapons, anti-aircraft missiles, grenades, explosive devices, and weapons prepared for future attacks, such as motorbikes intended for kidnapping," had been found; the officer also stated that booby-trapped homes had been encountered, and that a booby-trapped mosque had been blown up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651690,00.html|title=IDF uncovers kidnapping tunnel|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
The United Nations Security Council held a four-hour meeting in New York attended by [[Mahmoud Abbas]], President of the [[Palestinian National Authority]], the UN Secretary-General, [[David Miliband]] (foreign secretary of the United Kingdom), and [[Condoleezza Rice]] (US Secretary of State), where all sides stated their view of the situation.<ref name="UN_SPV6061_2009">{{UN document |docid=S-PV-6061 |date=6 January 2009 |type=Verbatim Report |body=Security Council |meeting=6061 |accessdate=10 January 2009|title=The situation in the Middle East, including the Palestinian question}}</ref>
=====UNRWA school Incident===== {{further|Al-Fakhura school incident}}
Palestinian medics in Gaza stated, and news agencies worldwide reported, that 43 people were killed in an Israeli strike on an [[UNRWA]] school.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE5053R720090107 | work=Reuters | title=Israel pounds Gaza again | date=7 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/01/2009169564177230.html|title=Scores killed as Gaza UN school hit|work=aljazeera.net}}</ref> The UN clarified in February that the shells had struck outside the school, not within the compound. Maxwell Gaylord (the UN humanitarian coordinator in Jerusalem) said that the UN "would like to clarify that the shelling and all of the fatalities took place outside and not inside the school."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/VDUX-7NVTZ9?OpenDocument|title=Field Update on Gaza from the Humanitarian Coordinator 30 Jan - 02 Feb 2009 as of 17:00}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1061189.html|title=UN backtracks on claim that deadly IDF strike hit Gaza school}}</ref> John Ging, UNRWA's operations director in Gaza stated he had been misquoted by the Jerusalem Post and other newspapers as saying that shells had hit the school, and that the UNRWA's earliest report on 6 January was correct in saying that shells had hit outside it.<ref name=4FebJP>{{cite news|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1233304655600&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull|title=UN: IDF did not shell UNRWA school|publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]}}</ref>
Two tank shells exploded outside the school, spraying shrapnel on people inside and outside the building, where at least 350 Palestinians had sought refuge from fighting between Israelis and Palestinians.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20090106/ts_nm/us_palestinians_israel Israeli shells kill 42 at U.N. school: Gaza medics - Yahoo! News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=Independent0601>{{cite news|title='40 killed at UN school' in Gaza|author=Reuters|publisher=The Independent|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/40-killed-at-un-school-in-gaza-1229250.html | location=London}}</ref> The strike took place near the Al-Fakhura school in Jabaliya in northern Gaza and was the third deadly Israeli attack near United Nations-run schools on 6 January.<ref name=IC>Agence France Presse (6 January 2009). "Israel says mortar may have fired from hit UN school". ''IC Publications'' Retrieved on 6 January 2009</ref>
The IDF said mortars from inside the school were fired at Israeli forces, and that Israeli soldiers were responding to them.<ref name="Haaretz6Jan30gUNidf">{{cite news|title=At least 30 Gazans killed in strike on UN school; IDF: Troops fired in self-defense |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053138.html|publisher=[[Haaretz]]}}</ref><ref name=ynetUNRWAschool>{{cite web|title=IDF: Mortars fired from bombed school|author=Hanan Greenberg |publisher=[[ynet]]|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3651722,00.html}}</ref> The IDF also stated that bodies of militants were found inside the school afterwards.<ref name="Haaretz6Jan30gUNidf"/> Time magazine reported, "The IDF gave the names of two Hamas combatants it says were killed inside the school — Imad and Hassan Abu Askar — who allegedly fired the mortars. But the IDF did not explain how it was able to identify them among the many casualties. Troops did not visit the school after the attack, nor did the IDF have access to a casualty list from Gaza's hospitals.".<ref name="Time7Jan">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1870087,00.html|title=UN: No Hamas Fighters in Bombed Gaza School|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=7 Jan 2009}}</ref> Nevertheless, Col. Moshe Levi (head of the IDF's Gaza Coordination and Liaison Administration) said, in February 2009, that 12 were the Palestinians killed in the incident - nine Hamas operatives and three noncombatants.<ref>http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1233304788684&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull</ref> Hamas rejected the claims of any fire from the school, calling them "baseless".<ref name=BBC_School>{{cite news|title=Strike at Gaza school kills 30|publisher=BBC|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7814054.stm}}</ref>
UNRWA spokesperson Christopher Gunness stated that the IDF later admitted in closed-door meetings that the fire they responded to was from outside the school.<ref name="DNow8JanUNRWAcg">{{cite news|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/1/8/headlines#2|title=School Bombing Toll Reaches 46 as Israel Retracts Claim of Militant Fire|publisher=Democracy Now, the war and peace report|work=Headlines for 08 January 2009|accessdate=23 Jan 2009}}"I've been authorized to say that the Israeli army, in private briefings with diplomats, is admitting that the firing that came out of Jabalya yesterday, the militant fire, was not from within the UNRWA school compound, it was from outside the UNRWA school compound." - C. Gunness, [[UNRWA]]</ref> He noted that the UN buildings that had been fired upon displayed the UN flag, and that the UN had provided GPS coordinates of UN schools sheltering civilians to the IDF.<ref name="DNow8JanUNRWAcg"/><ref name="ocha_report_1_7">{{Cite news | title = Situation Report From The Humanitarian Coordinator - 7 January 2009, 1700 hours | url = http://www.ochaopt.org/documents/ocha_opt_gaza_humanitarian_situation_report_2009_01_07_english.pdf | date = 7 January 2009 | agency = [[UN]] [[Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] | accessdate = 7 January 2009 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5dewG3QSd?url=http://www.ochaopt.org/documents/ocha_opt_gaza_humanitarian_situation_report_2009_01_07_english.pdf | archivedate = 7 January 2009 }}"UNRWA shelters are marked and their GPS locations are provided to the IDF"</ref> Days earlier Gunness had said that the UNRWA was "99.9% certain" that there were no terrorists or military activity in the school, adding that this "does not necessarily contradict Israel's claim that the militants were operating close by".<ref name="haaretz_Gunness">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053455.html|title=UN Rejects IDF Claim Gaza Militants Operated From Bombed-out School|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref>
Palestinian [[President of the Palestinian National Authority|President]] [[Mahmoud Abbas]] was said by an aide to be investigating the option of bringing the incident before international courts.<ref name="ReutersEgyptTrucePlan">{{cite news|title=Egypt floats truce plan after 42 killed in Gaza school|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/vcCandidateFeed2/idUSL7214076._CH_.2400|author1=Nidal al-Mughrabi |author2=Dan Williams |author3=Adam Entous |author4=Aziz el-Kaissouni |author5=Claudia Parsons |author6=Louis Charbonneau |date=7 January 2009|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
The day of the attack, the UN requested an inquiry into both the assault and the Israeli allegations about terrorists firing from its schools. [[Ban Ki Moon]] condemned the attack, saying it was "totally unacceptable."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=29472&Cr=Palestin&Cr1=|title=Ban condemns ‘unacceptable’ Israeli strikes on UN schools in Gaza|publisher=[[United Nations]]|work=UN News Centre|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=23 Jan 2009}}</ref>
====7 January 2009====
At least 12 [[Palestinians]] were killed in fresh strikes in the [[Gaza Strip]]. At least 15 rockets hit Israel, causing no casualties.<ref name="reuters1"/>
Following the strikes, [[Israel]] initiated a three-hour "humanitarian" truce. The [[Israeli army]] refrained from attacks from 1 to 4 pm, though there were reports of exchanges of fire between Israeli forces and Hamas during that period. During the temporary truce, 80 aid trucks were allowed to enter the Strip, some of which delivered industrial fuel to Gaza's power plant. Access was granted to previously closed regions, to allow residents access to supplies. According to Israeli sources, they planned to repeat this move daily. Fighting resumed immediately following the end of the truce.<ref name="Haaretz_truce">{{cite web|title=Clashes resume in Gaza City after 3-hour humanitarian truce |url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1053498.html| publisher=[[Haaretz]]|date=7 January 2009|accessdate=7 January 2009|author=Reuters}}</ref>
Despite the parties’ agreement to halt fighting during aid deliveries, a UN convoy was fired upon, killing an aid worker and wounding two others. Israeli tank fire was mentioned as the cause of the incident, but the IDF denied responsibility. Soldiers contended that Hamas snipers had targeted the aid workers. An Israeli medic said the wounded were saved by the Israelis, while the Palestinian Red Crescent Society denied it and said it had evacuated the victims.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090218191120/http://www.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424892324&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull ''Uncertainty shrouds UN driver's death'']. AMIR MIZROCH, Jerusalem Post, 8 January 2009</ref> The Jerusalem Post wrote that the two wounded Palestinians had gunshot wounds and probably were hit by Hamas gunfire. While the UNRWA director acknowledged he could not be absolutely certain that the attacks came from IDF forces, an UNRWA spokesman blamed the Israelis for sending mixed contradicting messages<ref>{{cite web|title=IDF: Army didn't fire on UN truck driver|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424908570&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull|date=10 January 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5djd1poP6?url=http://www.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424908570&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull|archivedate=11 January 2009|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As a result of the incident, the UN briefly suspended aid shipments but resumed them on 9 January after receiving assurances from Israel that they were not being targeted.<ref name=Independent0801>{{cite news|title=UN pulls out of Gaza over fears for its staff|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=8 January 2009|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/un-pulls-out-of-gaza-over-fears-for-its-staff-1237098.html | location=London | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="ynetnews_UNaid_Jan9">{{cite web|title=UN aid workers plan to resume Gaza movement soon|author=[[Reuters]]|publisher=[[ynetnews]]|date=9 January 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3653571,00.html}}</ref>
====8 January 2009==== At least two dozen Israeli airstrikes were reported, in which at least 4 Palestinians were killed and at least 22 wounded.<ref name="fjparticle1">[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231167313355&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull 3 soldiers killed as IDF pushes deeper into northern Gaza cities | Confronting Hamas | Jerusalem Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> UN officials said at least one driver in a UN aid convoy was killed after the convoy was fired upon by Israeli forces.<ref name=AlJazeera0801>{{cite web|title=Israel 'fires on UN Gaza convoy'|author=Al Jazeera and agencies|publisher=Al Jazeea English|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/01/2009181119551714.html|date=8 January 2009|accessdate=8 January 2009}}</ref> The UN said the attack happened in spite of co-ordinating its movements with the IDF. It subsequently said it would suspend all relief activities in Gaza until it had received guarantees of the safety of its staff from Israel.<ref name=Christian_Science_monitor>{{cite web|title=United Nations halts relief work in Gaza|author=Joshua MItnick|publisher=Christian Science Monitor|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0109/p25s14-wome.html|date=8 January 2009|accessdate=8 January 2009}}</ref><ref name=International_Herald_Tribune>{{cite web|title=Pressure increases on Israel as toll rises|author=Graham Bowley|publisher=International Herald Tribune|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/08/mideast/mideast.php|date=8 January 2009|accessdate=8 January 2009}}</ref>
Israel announced the deaths of three soldiers: Roi Rosner, Amit Robinson, and Omer Rabinovitch, bringing the total number of soldiers killed to eight.<ref name="fjparticle1"/><ref name=YNET0801>{{cite web|title=IDF soldier killed by sniper fire in Gaza|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3653153,00.html|publisher=[[YNET]]|date=8 January 2009|accessdate=8 January 2009}}</ref> Israel also claimed that many Hamas fighters were killed.
Three Katyusha rockets from [[Lebanon]] territory were fired at the northern Israeli city of Nahariyya. Two civilians were injured. The IDF returned fire at the launch sites in southern Lebanon. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231167307373&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Several lightly wounded as Katyushas hit Nahariya area] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001162855/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231167307373&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull |date=1 October 2011 }}, retrieved on 8 January 2009</ref>
The United Nations Security Council met and passed a resolution "stressing the urgency of and calls for an immediate, durable and fully respected ceasefire, leading to the full withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza", and welcoming the Egyptian initiative, among other points.<ref name="UN_SRES18602009">{{UN document |docid=S-RES-1860(2009) |type=Resolution |body=Security Council |year=2009 |resolution_number=1860 |accessdate=15 January 2009|date=8 January 2009}}</ref> While the [[United States]] abstained on the vote, [[Condoleezza Rice]] explained to the Council that the U.S. thought it important to see the outcomes of the Egyptian mediation efforts in order to see what the resolution might have been supporting, but that "after a great deal of consideration, we decided that the resolution -- the text of which we support, the goals of which we support and the objectives of which we fully support -- should indeed be allowed to go forward."{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}
The order to abstain on the resolution, which U.S. diplomats had helped to draft, reportedly came at the last minute from President Bush, following pressure from the Israeli government, who issued a statement that the resolution was "not practical".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/09/gaza-us-security-council-abstention|title=White House 'behind' US volte-face on ceasefire call 9 January 2009|publisher=The Guardian | location=London | first=Julian | last=Borger | date=9 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> In an unusually public rebuke, the Israeli Prime Minister boasted of how he had phoned up President Bush while Bush was in the middle of a speech, and how the incident left Rice "pretty embarrassed".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/13/america/13olmert.php|title=Olmert says he made Rice change vote|date=13 January 2009|first=Mark|last=Landler}}</ref>
====9 January 2009==== The Israeli offensive continued, despite the passing of a UN Security resolution calling for an immediate and durable ceasefire.
Israel dismissed the Security Council resolution as "impractical": Ehud Olmert's office said that more Hamas rockets "only prove that the U.N.'s decision is not practical and will not be kept in practice by the Palestinian murder organizations."<ref name="palestinians1">[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090110/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_israel_palestinians Israel tells Gazans to brace for war escalation - Yahoo! News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Hamas objected to not being consulted during the drafting of the resolution: "Nobody consulted Hamas or talked to Hamas. Nobody put Hamas in the picture and yet Hamas is required to accept it. This is unacceptable," Mohammed Nazzal, a senior Hamas official based in Syria, told Al-Arabiya television.<ref name="palestinians1"/>
At least 30 rockets were fired at southern Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054247.html|title=Gaza Rocket Hits Playground in Ashdod, Amid Barrage on Negev|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref> Hamas claimed to have hit the [[Tel Nof]] airbase, some {{convert|27|km|mi}} from Tel Aviv, which, if true, would make it the farthest strike to date.<ref name=Melman>{{cite web|title=Hamas claims it hit IAF base 27km from Tel Aviv|author=Yossi Melman|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054233.html|date=10 January 2009|accessdate=10 January 2009|publisher=[[Haaretz]]}}</ref> Hamas also announced that Mahmoud Abbas' term as President had expired, and that while they do not expect Abbas to step down while the war continues in Gaza, they no longer recognize his legitimacy. Abbas responded that he still had another year, citing a law that says presidential and parliamentary elections should be held at the same time.<ref name=UPI0109>{{cite web|title=Hamas: Abbas no longer president|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/01/09/Hamas_Abbas_no_longer_president/UPI-19361231560412/|date=9 January 2009|accessdate=10 January 2009}}</ref>
Condoleezza Rice said that it was "difficult" to protect civilians in a place as densely populated as Gaza — an area {{convert|25|mi|km}} long and roughly six miles wide.<ref name="palestinians1"/> A UN report on Gaza noted that "the borders are closed, making this one of the rare conflicts where civilians have no place to flee."<ref name="ocha_report_1_7"/>
A three-hour truce took place on 9 January. Palestinians fired three Grad-type rockets at Ashdod, shortly after 1 pm, the truce's start-time. While supplies were being transferred through [[Kerem Shalom]] border crossing, Palestinians fired several mortar shells at the terminal. No casualties were reported.<ref name=jpost_jan9_truce>{{cite web|title=Mortar shells fired at Kerem Shalom|publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]|date=9 January 2009|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424898375&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull}}</ref>
The UN said its aid workers would resume movement, having received assurances from Israel that they were not being targeted.<ref name="ynetnews_UNaid_Jan9"/>
At around 23:00, an Israeli [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]] destroyed a [[Norwegian People's Aid]] (NPA) car that was clearly marked with the NPA logo, outside the home of an NPA employee, Mahmoud Hamada, at [[al-Shati (camp)|al-Shati refugee camp]] in northern Gaza. Nobody was injured. Surrounding buildings were severely damaged. The Secretary-General of NPA, [[Petter Eide]], said that there are no military targets in the area. Raymond Johansen of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] stated that the incident was a "clear violation of [[international law]]."<ref name="maan_NorwayPA">{{cite news | pages= | title=Norwegian People's Aid car hit by missile, Foreign Ministry calls incident "clear violation of international law" | date=10 January 2009 | publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] | url=http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&ID=34840 | accessdate=11 January 2009 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5djZcDjrj?url=http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&ID=34840 | archivedate=11 January 2009 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="NPA1101">{{cite web| title =NPA car hit by missile in Gaza| work =| publisher =Norwegian People’s Aid| date =10 January 2009| url =http://www.npaid.org/?module=Articles;action=Article.publicShow;ID=7254| format =| doi =| accessdate =11 January 2009| archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/5djfRPZza?url=http://www.npaid.org/?module=Articles;action=Article.publicShow;ID=7254| archivedate =11 January 2009| deadurl =yes| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
====10 January 2009==== No rockets were fired into Israel overnight, a sharp drop from the dozens of projectiles that were launched in the early days of the offensive; during the morning, three rockets struck the southern city of Ashkelon, lightly wounding two people. Six additional rockets landed in open areas, with no casualties.<ref name="palestinians1"/><ref name="Haaretz_rockets_Jan10">{{cite web|title= Gaza rockets strike Ashkelon, injuring two Israelis |author=Yanir Yagna|publisher=[[Haaretz]]|date=10 January 2009|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054247.html}}</ref>
The Israeli military said that in Gaza it had killed more than 15 terrorists and that IDF aircraft had attacked more than 40 targets throughout Gaza striking ten rocket-launching sites, weapons-storage facilities, smuggling tunnels, an anti-aircraft missile launcher and gunmen. Although Palestinian hospital officials could confirm only four deaths they also stated that fighting has hindered paramedics from collecting bodies and treating the wounded. Palestinian medical officials said that eight people were killed by Israeli tank fire Saturday in the town of Jebailiya and the dead appeared to be civilians per paramedics on the scene.<ref name="palestinians1"/>
The Israeli military said it would halt the fire in Gaza for three hours on Saturday to allow the territory's besieged residents to leave their homes and stock up on supplies. Medics use the lull to rescue casualties in areas of fighting, and aid groups also rush through food distribution.<ref name="palestinians1"/>
The Palestinian Authority president urged both Israel and Hamas to agree to an Egypt-brokered truce Saturday, but he singled out Israel, saying it would be responsible for a "waterfall of blood" if it didn't accept the deal.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090110/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_mideast_diplomacy Palestinian leader says 'aggression' must stop - Yahoo! News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
On 10 January the IDF stated that Hamas fighters are suffering from exhaustion. An IDF military commander said that Hamas militants are beginning to desert battle and refuse orders. Israeli military claims that Hamas younger operatives refused to venture outside to lob mortars against Israeli forces, prompting a senior Hamas leader, Amir Mansi, to operate the mortar himself. After IDF soldiers identified the source of fire, they shot and killed Mansi, wounding two others involved in the attack. Amir Mansi has been reported as an expert in the Grad rocket launching program, having been trained by Hezbollah. Also, the IDF stated that more than 300 Hamas fighters have been killed so far in the operation, the highest estimate so far, and at least 120 have been captured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054245.html|title=IDF: Hamas Men Beginning to Desert; Army Steps Up Gaza Op|work=Haaretz.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117011018/http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054245.html|archivedate=17 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the reports, entire Hamas companies have been eliminated by the Israeli forces. A senior Israeli officer said that "complete battalions that have just been erased", adding that Hamas fighters are afraid to come out to fight, with many going [[desertion|AWOL]] and abandoning the battlefield.<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424911728&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Defense officials: IDF likely to expand Gaza op | Confronting Hamas | Jerusalem Post<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121012630/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424911728&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull |date=21 January 2012 }}</ref>
====11 January 2009==== [[File:GazaWPshelling.gif|thumbnail|Phosphorus cluster bombs dropped on populated areas on 11 January]]
The [[Israeli Air Force|IAF]] attacked overnight a [[mosque]] in the town of [[Rafah]], which according to Israel was being used as a Hamas training camp, a meeting place and a weapons cache. The [[Israeli Defence Forces|IDF]] reported that the mosque contained machine-guns and [[anti-aircraft]] missiles.<ref name=ynet_reportJan11>{{cite news|title=Gaza Report: IDF kills 10 Palestinian gunmen |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3654019,00.html|publisher = [[YNET]]|date=11 January 2009}}</ref>
Israeli and Palestinian officials report that at least 40 [[Hamas]] gunmen were killed in a battle with [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] soldiers in the Gaza City neighborhood of [[Sheikh Ajalin]]. According to reports, Hamas and [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine|Islamic Jihad]] terrorists ambushed IDF forces in Sheikh Ajalin, which led to "some of the heaviest fighting" since phase two of the operation began.<ref name="fjparticle2">[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424914146&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Army creating 'security zone' in Gaza | Confronting Hamas | Jerusalem Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Palestinians reported that four people had been killed in the northern town of [[Beit Lahiya]]. The IDF reported hitting dozens of gunmen across the Gaza Strip on 10 January and 11.<ref name=ynet_reportJan11/> Additionally, the IAF reported that Hamas operatives have tried to shoot down an IAF fixed wing aircraft with anti-aircraft missiles for the first time since operation in Gaza begun.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054497.html|title=Sources: Hamas Fired Anti-aircraft Missiles at IAF Planes|work=Haaretz.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117011118/http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054497.html|archivedate=17 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Two rockets landed in the city of Beersheba, a half an hour before the city's high schools were to reopen after being closed for more than 10 days. Some 65% of Beersheba's 11 and 12th graders (about 2.700 students) were to return to school and study in bomb shelters.<ref name=ynet_reportJan11_rockets>{{cite news|title=Rockets hit Beersheba as youths head to school |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3653936,00.html |publisher = [[YNET]]|date=11 January 2009}}</ref>
Two terrorists and a woman were killed by Israeli strikes in the southern Gaza Strip. Dozens were injured in attacks near the village of Khouza to the east of Khan Younis. Palestinian medics in the area said that the injured suffered from burns and gas inhalations, symptoms indicating exposure to white phosphorus. Israel rejected the claim.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gaza hit by new Israeli strikes|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7822623.stm|date=11 January 2009 | work=BBC News}}</ref>
There have been rumors circulating in the Egyptian media that IAF strikes have wounded the captive Israeli soldier [[Gilad Shalit]]. A spokesman of Hamas politburo, [[Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook|Moussa Abu Marzuk]], said that Shalit's condition is no longer a concern for Hamas. An Israeli Defense Ministry official dismissed the comments as "psychological warfare".<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054469.html Report: Hamas official says Shalit's fate is no longer group's concern - Haaretz - Israel News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Vice Premier [[Haim Ramon]] in an interview with Army Radio added that Hamas is using Shalit as a "bargaining chip" hoping for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in exchange for the captured soldier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1050915.html|title=Report: Captive IDF Soldier Shalit Wounded in Gaza Air Strikes|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref>
On 11 January, the IDF started to deploy thousands of reservists into the Gaza Strip for the first time since Israeli offensive against Hamas begun 16 days ago. The Israeli government announced that it had approved tens of thousands of call-ups of its reserve forces before the ground operation started on 3 January. The troops have been refreshing on their urban training since then, and the bulk of the fighting has been done by [[Golani Brigade|Golani]] and [[Givati Brigade|Givati]] brigades. Analysts comment that this suggests Israel is intensifying its military efforts against Hamas.<ref name="fjparticle2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054531.html|title=IDF Begins Deploying Reservists Into Gaza as Part of Ground Op|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref>
An Israeli patrol came under fire on the Syrian border on Sunday. The soldiers did not return fire and no casualties were reported, although the vehicle they were traveling in sustained damage. The IDF assessed that the [[Military of Syria|Syrian army]] was not involved, believing it was Palestinians protesting the Gaza operation. It was the second cross-border attack in three days after three [[Katyusha rocket launcher|Katyusha]] rockets were fired into northern Israel on 8 January from Lebanon. Israel filed a complaint to the [[United Nations Disengagement Observer Force Zone|UNDOF]] in [[Syria]] which sent a team to investigate the reports.<ref>[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424924849&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Gunshots fired from Syria at Golan | Israel | Jerusalem Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://cnnwire.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/11/un-investigates-gunfire-at-israel-syria-border/ | work=CNN | title=U.N. investigates gunfire at Israel-Syria border | accessdate=25 May 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
The [[Israeli Defence Forces|IDF]] reported that it had uncovered an [[explosive device]] rigged with a [[timer]] that was hidden in a Palestinian school. A [[Fuse (explosives)|fuse]] attached to the explosives extended to a [[Gaza Zoo|zoo]] located dozens of yards away. The soldiers managed to neutralize the bomb before it went off. According to the IDF, numerous weapons, including [[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]] launchers, [[grenades]] and [[AK-47]] assault rifles were found inside the school.<ref name = ynet_school_zoo>{{cite web|title=Gaza: IDF uncovers booby-trapped school, zoo| publisher= [[YNET]] |date=11 January 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3654407,00.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hamas Booby Trapped School and Zoo|author=[[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] |publisher=IDF Spokesperson's Unit |date=11 January 2009|accessdate=11 January 2009|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uHhs9ihSmbU}}</ref>
In the afternoon, during the "humanitarian corridor" - a time in which the Israeli army holds it fire and allows civilians in Gaza to receive aid - [[Hamas]] terrorists fired several rocket barrages. A rocket fired from the northern Gaza Strip hit a wall surrounding a kindergarten in [[Ashdod]]. There were no reports of damage or injury, but a few people were treated for shock. Other rockets were fired at [[Ashkelon]], [[Sderot]], [[Kiryat Malachi]], and [[Eshkol Regional Council]].<ref name = ynet_rockets_humanitarian>{{cite web|title=Rocket lands near Ashdod kindergarten; no injuries| publisher= [[YNET]] |date=11 January 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3654153,00.html}}</ref>
====12 January 2009==== On 12 January, four Israeli paratroopers were wounded in northern Gaza. A unit of Israeli paratroopers also discovered a Hamas tunnel, and shot and killed a female would-be suicide bomber. Israeli ground troops and aircraft targeted over 25 Hamas sites, including tunnels and weapons caches, killing four Hamas fighters and five civilians.<ref>[[Reuters]] - ''Israeli forces squeeze Gaza''</ref> Israeli forces continued their advance, with reports of fierce fighting around Gaza City. Airstrikes continued across the strip.<ref name="Timeline"/>
On 12 January, the IDF reported that it had started deploying reserve forces in Gaza.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Hanan|title=IDF incorporates reservists in Gaza op|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3654454,00.html|date=12 January 2009}}</ref>
The [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] reported on 12 January that four soldiers were wounded, one seriously. The troops were part of a [[paratrooper]] unit that was operating in northern Gaza. The military said they launched an inquiry whether this incident was caused by friendly fire.<ref name="haaretz1">{{cite web|url=http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054778.html|title=IDF Soldier Seriously Hurt in Gaza, Possibly by Friendly Fire|work=Haaretz.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115090736/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1054778.html|archivedate=15 January 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to previous reports friendly fire has so far killed four soldiers in separate incidents on 5 January.<ref name="ynetnews1"/><ref name="englishil"/> Hamas' armed wing, the Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigade, claimed to have destroyed two Israeli tanks in the Gaza City neighborhood of Zeitun, and that they killed many soldiers in the town of [[Khuza'a, Khan Yunis|Khuz'a]], near the Israeli border. The Israeli army refuted these claims.{{cn|date=September 2018}} Another paratrooper unit discovered and eventually destroyed a [[tunnel]] in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] that, according to the IDF, was meant to transfer [[suicide bomber]]s into Israel. The tunnel was found some 300 meters from the fence on the border with Israel. It was also reported that the soldiers shot and killed a female would-be suicide bomber.<ref name="haaretz1"/> During the day the military, backed by the IAF, targeted over 25 sites on Monday, including tunnels and weapon caches, killing 9 Palestinians, five of whom, according to Palestinian officials, were civilians.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE5053R720090113 | work=Reuters | title=Israeli forces squeeze Gaza | date=13 January 2009}}</ref>
US President [[George W. Bush]] threw his support behind Israel once more on 12 January. The President was quoted with saying that he believes a sustainable [[ceasefire]] will only be achieved if [[Hamas]] stops firing [[Qassam rocket|rockets]] at Israel and that it is solely Hamas' choice to make. He reiterated Israel's right to defend herself but hoped she "continued to be mindful of the innocent folk" and help with humanitarian aid transfer into Gaza.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE5053R720090113?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=10112 | work=Reuters | title=Israeli forces squeeze Gaza | date=13 January 2009}}</ref> Meanwhile, it was reported that Hamas raided over 100 trucks with humanitarian aid meant for civilians and sold it to the highest bidder. Israeli forces stopped several attempts to smuggle prohibited goods into Israel, namely electronics, since Defense Minister [[Ehud Barak]] said they do not classify as humanitarian aid. Israel still allows certain repair items to flow into Gaza to repair the damaged electric grid.<ref name="fjparticle3">[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231424932109&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Hamas raids aid trucks, sells supplies | Confronting Hamas | Jerusalem Post<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001164132/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull&cid=1231424932109 |date=1 October 2011 }}</ref>
Israel is considering establishing a [[field hospital]] outside of the Gaza Strip to facilitate medical aid for Palestinians civilians wounded in the conflict between Israel and Hamas. Under the plan, Israel is also considering bringing the facility inside the Palestinian territory to make it more accessible for the Palestinians seeking treatment. The hospital would be run by the IDF Medical Corps. Throughout the conflict, IDF has allowed the passage of over 900 trucks and facilitated with the transfer of over 20,000 tons of basic food and supplies.<ref name="fjparticle3"/>
As the Palestinian death toll exceeded 900, in a statement the IDF said it believes 400 of those are known Hamas fighters, adding that a "significant number are also Hamas operatives" in the remaining 500 dead.<ref name="fjparticle3"/>
====13 January 2009==== Israel's land, sea and air bombardment continues for an 18th day, with shelling and air raids hitting Gaza City, Rafah and elsewhere. Israel's military says it hit 60 targets overnight. Ground troops advance into the southern and eastern suburbs of Gaza City. The Israeli military says an officer and two soldiers are injured by an explosion in a booby-trapped house in the northern Gaza Strip.<ref name="middle1">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7812290.stm | work=BBC News | title=Gaza conflict: Timeline | date=18 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
An unidentified gunman opened fire at an Israeli Border Guard patrol from the Jordanian side of the border north of Eilat early Tuesday morning. The Border Guards returned fire. No one was injured in the incident, the first such shooting in more than a decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/129397|title=Jordanian Gunman Opens Fire - Defense/Middle East - News - Arutz Sheva|work=Arutz Sheva}}</ref>
====14 January 2009==== Israel's bombardment continues for a 19th day, with overnight air raids on 60 targets, including 35 weapons-smuggling tunnels on the border with Egypt and an unknown number of rocket-launching sites. One air strike damages a cemetery in Gaza City. Israel was targeted from the Lebanese border. Israeli troops counterattacked.<ref name="middle1"/> No casualties were reported on either side. A message, allegedly by [[Osama Bin Laden]], was released declaring [[Jihad]] on Israel.<ref name="Bin Laden calls for a Jihad A Call for Jihad to stop the aggression on Gaza. ">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/01/14/terror/main4720357.shtml|title=Bin Laden: U.S. Decline Fueled Gaza Attack|last=Wassef|first=Khaled|author2=Tucker Reals |date=14 January 2009|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=14 January 2009}}</ref>
====15 January 2009==== Israeli tanks and troops advance deep into Gaza City after an intense bombardment in the early hours, sending hundreds of terrified civilians into the streets to try to flee the fighting. Tonnes of aid go up in flames after Israeli artillery shells hit a UN compound. The Quds hospital is evacuated because of a fire caused by a tank shell. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon meets Israeli leaders to push for a ceasefire. He says the death toll, put at 1,100 by Gaza medical officials, has reached an "unbearable point".<ref name="middle1"/>
Two rockets fired by Gaza militants on Thursday hit Be'er Sheva, wounding five people, including a 7-year-old boy who was seriously hurt. One of the rockets landed directly on a car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1055759.html|title=Boy, 7, seriously hurt as Gaza rockets slam into Be'er Sheva|date=15 January 2009|publisher=HaAretz|accessdate=15 January 2009}}</ref>
In a battle near Jebaliya, an IDF soldier was killed and another was severely wounded. The IAF attacked over 15 sites, including rocket-launching sites and squads, gunmen, and a smuggling tunnel. The IDF also said that 40 Hamas operatives have been killed overnight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/159356|title=IDF Targets Three Senior Hamas Terrorists - Latest News Briefs - Arutz Sheva|work=Arutz Sheva}}</ref>
Three senior members of Hamas, [[Said Seyam]], the Hamas interior minister and his brother Ayad Seyam and an unidentified person was killed in an IAF strike on Ayad Seyam's house. 20 other people were reportedly injured in the same strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3656955,00.html|title=Israel says killed Hamas interior minister|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> Palestinian sources said that the head of Islamist terrorist group's security apparatus, Salah Abu Shreh, and its military commander in Gaza City, Mahmoud Watfah, were also killed in the attack. Hamas, despite the truce proposal, vowed revenge for the assassination of Seyam, who was one of the masterminds of the 2007 coup against the ruling party, [[Fatah]] and was the number three most sought Hamas leader after Ismail Haniyeh and Mahmoud Zahar. [[Shin Bet]] security agency, the Israeli equivalent of the [[FBI]], were responsible for the intelligence leading to the airstrike that killed Seyam.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1055899.html|title=Hamas Vows Revenge After IDF Kills Gaza Interior Minister Said Sayyam|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref>
It is reported by several people, journalist and doctors that the Israeli army fired upon the UNRWA compound, schools, ambulances, hospitals and media offices. In response to this, Ban Ki-moon, UN secretary general, has started a protest.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/01/15/gaza.aid.plea/?iref=hpmostpop | work=CNN | title=Third-ranking Hamas leader in Gaza killed - CNN.com | date=15 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5izuM7SKx3W0YpgR1HLtN7BrALbEA AFP: Israel kills senior Hamas leader as strikes set Gaza ablaze<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,480009,00.html | work=Fox News | title=Explosion Blasts Media Offices in Gaza | date=15 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/4247659/Israeli-strikes-hit-Gaza-hospitals-and-UN-aid-headquarters.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Israeli strikes hit Gaza hospitals and UN aid headquarters | first=Tim | last=Butcher | date=15 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
====16 January 2009==== The bodies of 23 Palestinians were pulled from the rubble in the Tel al-Hawa district of Gaza City after Israeli tanks withdraw in the pre-dawn hours. Palestinian medics say at least 1,155 Palestinians have died over the past three weeks.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7812290.stm | work=BBC News | title=Gaza conflict: Timeline | date=18 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip on Friday, 16 January, fired over 15 rockets at southern Israel, leaving five Israelis wounded: a pregnant woman was hospitalized in Ashkelon after her home suffered a direct hit from a rocket; two were wounded in Ashdod - one moderately and the other lightly; earlier three Israelis sustained light wounds when two Grad rockets struck the southern town of Kiryat Gat; five rockets exploded in the Eshkol region in the morning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1056149.html|title=Pregnant woman hospitalized as rocket hits home in Ashkelon|date=16 January 2009|publisher=HaAretz|accessdate=16 January 2009}}</ref>
====17 January 2009==== More than 50 air strikes were carried out in Gaza overnight, ahead of the expected vote by Israel's cabinet on a proposal for a ceasefire. Heavy explosions echoed south of Gaza City.
United Nations officials say two children, aged five and seven, were killed when Israeli tank fire hit a UN school where hundreds had taken shelter in the northern town of Beit Lahiya. A UN spokesman, Chris Gunness, said an investigation ought to be held "to determine whether a war crime has been committed". Israeli foreign ministry spokesman Yigal Palmor rejected the call, saying: "There's not the slightest piece of evidence to support such allegations."<ref name="middle1"/>
====18 January 2009==== Israel implemented a unilateral cease-fire early Sunday and in announcing the cease-fire late Saturday, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel had achieved its goals and more, stating that "Hamas was hit hard, in its military arms and in its government institutions. Its leaders are in hiding and many of its men have been killed." According to Olmert's statement, the cease-fire went into effect at 2 a.m. local time (00.00 GMT) with the IDF warning that attacks on soldiers or civilians "will be met with a harsh response." If Hamas holds its fire, the military "will weigh pulling out of Gaza at a time that befits us," Olmert said. If not, Israel "will continue to act to defend our residents."<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090118/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_israel_palestinians Israel pulling out of Gaza; Hamas ceases fire - Yahoo! News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The first death after the cease-fire was a Palestinian farmer who was shot dead by Israeli soldier while checking his farm in [[Khan Younis]], on 18 January morning. The Israeli army said they shot the farmer because he was approaching land occupied at that moment by Israeli ground troops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-01/18/content_10678349.htm|title=First Palestinian shot dead after Israel's unilateral ceasefire_English_Xinhua|publisher=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
Hamas fired ten rockets into Southern Israel, Israel responded with airstrikes.<ref name="cosmoscl">[http://cosmos.bcst.yahoo.com/up/player/popup/?rn=3906861&cl=11593016&ch=4226714&src=news Yahoo!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Hamas made a televised announcement of a ceasefire issuing their own demands of Israeli withdrawal within a week, reopen Gaza border crossings, and provide aid.<ref name="cosmoscl"/>
====20 January 2009==== On Tuesday afternoon, Gaza gunmen fired at IDF patrols in two separate incidents near the Kissufim border crossing, in central Gaza, and in southern Gaza - IDF returned fire. No one was wounded and no significant damage was reported.<ref name="fjparticle4">[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1232292915656&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Jerusalem Post]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3659170,00.html|title=ynet אש נורתה אל חיילים בשני מוקדים ברצועה - חדשות|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> Also, eight mortar shells were fired from the central Gaza Strip. Most shells apparently landed in Palestinian areas. IAF targeted and hit one of the mortar launchers.<ref name="fjparticle4"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3659473,00.html|title=IDF: Palestinians fired 8 mortar shells Tuesday|work=ynet|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> Shelling of mortars continued Tuesday night and 3-4 shells were fired at [[Eshkol Regional Council]]. No casualties were reported.<ref name="walla_eshkol_rockets">{{cite news | title = מטח פצמ"רים לעבר מערב הנגב. אין נפגעים | publisher = [[walla]] | date = 20 January 2009 | url = http://news.walla.co.il/?w=/1/1421259}}</ref> On the same day, another Palestinian farmer was shot dead by the IDF while approaching his farm in [[Jabalia]] and two children were killed in an explosion of an Israeli bomb left behind in [[Gaza City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-01/20/content_10691181.htm|title=Medics: Palestinian farmer shot dead SE of Gaza_English_Xinhua|publisher=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&Do=&ID=35135 Maan News Agency<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====21 January 2009==== Early in the day, Israel said it had completed its troop pull-out from Gaza.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7841902.stm | work=BBC News | title=Last Israeli troops 'leave Gaza' | date=21 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
====22 January 2009==== In the wake of the conflict, Hamas accused rival Palestinian faction Fatah of spying for Israel. Fatah denied spying on Hamas for Israel, and party leaders said Thursday that at least 175 of their members had been rounded up and tortured in recent days.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/01/22/gaza.hamas/index.html | work=CNN | title=Rival factions trade accusations of spying, violence in Gaza - CNN.com | date=22 January 2009 | accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
